image.altText: a blonde woman wearing glasses, a hard hat and a high-vis vest.

props.synopsis: Jacinta Allan has emerged from a Victorian Labor caucus meeting as the premier-elect, after long-time leader Daniel Andrews announced he was calling time on the job after nine years.

title.children: Jacinta Allan fends off late challenge to become 49th premier of Victoria

image.altText: Nick Sallese and Margate road sign.

props.synopsis: A casual conversation at a tip-shop in Tasmania's south almost 15 years ago between a man not seen since 2008 and an acquaintance could be the missing clue a family has been desperately waiting for, the man's son says.

title.children: Old sighting of missing man sparks new hope for family desperate for answers

image.altText: A sign for the Launceston General Hospital and the Ashley Youth Detention Centre behind an obscured man.

props.synopsis: It was described as a landmark report into how Tasmanian authorities handled allegations of child sexual abuse in hospitals, schools, detention and out-of-home care. So what did it say?

title.children: 'We continue to be worried': The key takeaways from Tasmania's landmark abuse report

image.altText: Handcuffed prisoner being led in corridor by warden.

props.synopsis: Child sexual abuse at Tasmania's only youth detention facility "remains a live and current risk" and not a historical problem, a two-year inquiry finds. The state premier says he would close it now if he could but there are no other options for housing child inmates.

title.children: Sexual abuse of children in a notorious youth prison a 'current risk', damning report finds

image.altText: Four women stand on a lawn and hug

props.synopsis: Tasmania's commission of inquiry into child sexual abuse sheds light on a litany of failures, with allegations covered up, ignored, or not believed. The premier has committed to change but has a big job ahead of him, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: 'We must not look away': Big job ahead for Tasmanian government after abuse report tabled

image.altText: Jacinta Allan speaks to journalists outdoors.

props.synopsis: Jacinta Allan has been elected unopposed as Victoria's new premier after Daniel Andrews's resignation, with Ben Carroll as deputy. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Jacinta Allan to replace Daniel Andrews as premier of Victoria

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader. She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Watch the press conference live

children.content: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader.
She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: State political reporter Bridget Rollason says a decision has been reached, with Jacinta Allan to be the next Victorian premier. Ben Carroll hasn't walked away empty handed though.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jacinta Allan to be the next premier of Victoria

children.content: State political reporter Bridget Rollason says a decision has been reached, with
Jacinta Allan to be the next Victorian premier
Ben Carroll hasn't walked away empty handed though.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: State political reporter Richard Willingham reckons this means we could be in for a long wait for a result: A ballot of the Victorian ALP to help elect a new Premier looms with sources in caucus saying Ben Carroll has nominated for the premier's job. A contest means that a ballot of members will be held, which will take weeks. The election is weighted 50 per cent caucus vote, 50 per cent membership vote. MPs report that negotiations are continuing in the room and that the situation is complex. Some MPs are angry at the decision, saying it risks stability. Others say it sends a clear message that the old way of doing things — having deals stitched up before voting — will no longer be tolerated .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It's official, Ben Carroll has nominated for the Victorian Labor leadership

children.content: State political reporter Richard Willingham reckons this means we could be in for a long wait for a result:
A ballot of the Victorian ALP to help elect a new Premier looms with sources in caucus saying Ben Carroll has nominated for the premier's job.
A contest means that a ballot of members will be held, which will take weeks. The election is weighted 50 per cent caucus vote, 50 per cent membership vote.
MPs report that negotiations are continuing in the room and that the situation is complex. Some MPs are
angry at the decision, saying it risks stability
Others say it sends a clear message that
the old way of doing things — having deals stitched up before voting — will no longer be tolerated

image.altText: Woman coughing or sneezing into her elbow at her desk with laptop in front of her

props.synopsis: There aren't any vaccines for or anti-viral drugs to treat human metapneumovirus (HMPV), but experts say there's no need to be alarmed.

title.children: Have you been sick lately? It might be this virus you 'probably don't know about'

image.altText: Noel Pearson by AAP Lukas Coch

props.synopsis: Leading Yes campaigner and Indigenous academic Noel Pearson has made an impassioned speech to the National Press Club pleading for Australians to support the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Only love can move us now': Pearson uses Voice as call for national unity

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation jumped to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, on rising

title.children: Monthly inflation lifts to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, according to ABS

image.altText: man in bed smiling

props.synopsis: A friend of critically ill surfing great Mark Richardson says his situation has become so dire that medical evacuation is his only chance of survival.

title.children: Surfing great to be evacuated to Australia as friend warns 'he'll die if he stays'

image.altText: Donald Trump Ivanka, Melania, Barron, and Don Jr stand together looking solemn

props.synopsis: A New York judge has ruled that former US president Donald Trump committed fraud when he lied about his wealth for a decade, defrauding banks and insurers as he built his real estate empire. So what is his real net worth?

title.children: A judge has ruled Donald Trump lied about his wealth. So how much is he worth?

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: A judge rules that Donald Trump committed fraud for years while building the real estate empire that catapulted him to fame and the White House.

title.children: Donald Trump defrauded banks for years, New York civil case rules

image.altText: Dr Peter Renshaw and LGH ward, composite image.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's child abuse inquiry delivers scathing findings against the former head of medical services at Launceston General Hospital over his handling of allegations against a notorious paedophile nurse.

title.children: Launceston hospital boss Peter Renshaw's 'omissions and fabrications' misled inquiry, commissioners find

image.altText: A person walks past the PwC welcome sign inside a building.

props.synopsis: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years.

title.children: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

image.altText: Rescued Green Tree snake on fence

props.synopsis: Snake catchers say it is becoming harder to find new homes for the reptiles as urban areas expand and the weather warms up.

title.children: 'They're bigger and nastier': Warmer weather brings bumper start to snake season

image.altText: A seal in the ocean near Hay Point

props.synopsis: A local angler who encountered the seal off the Mackay coast says it was "the weirdest and strangest thing" he has ever seen.

title.children: Seal spotted in North Queensland after 'very big swim' 2,000km north of usual home

image.altText: Two young people walk through a train station wearing face masks.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 became one of Australia's leading causes of death in 2022, data from the Bureau of Statistics shows, however heart disease remained the biggest killer.

title.children: For the first time in over 50 years, an infectious disease is a leading cause of death in Australia

image.altText: Someone adjusts the oxygen mask of a tuberculosis patient who is lying in a hospital bed

props.synopsis: The state's health authorities says there is no link to a previous outbreak in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands and no risk to the wider community.

title.children: Five active tuberculosis cases identified in South Australia's Murraylands region, including young child

image.altText: Screengrabs from Barbie and Oppenheimer

props.synopsis: Two new categories are set to shake up the Golden Globes and its 80-year history. Here's what we know and what it could mean for the 2024 awards season.

title.children: Blockbuster films and stand-up comedy. What do the new Golden Globe categories mean?

image.altText: Person's hand with blue nailpolish design holding onto the pill

props.synopsis: From today many women across New South Wales will no longer have to go to their GP every time they need a new script for the oral contraceptive pill. Here's how the expanded trial will work.

title.children: It's just been made easier in NSW to access the contraceptive pill. This is what's changing

image.altText: A man wearing a suit carrying a cup of coffee walks past a KPMG logo.

props.synopsis: Andrew Yates, CEO of KPMG Australia, told a Senate inquiry that the company is currently reviewing its donation policies. The big four consultancy firms have donated $4.3 million to major political parties over the past decade.

title.children: KPMG pauses political donations, inflation jumps again in Australia, ASX falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years. Without naming former chief executives Tom Seymour and Luke Sayers, who are no longer with the firm, the review found a "generally accepted view that the CEO 'runs the show' and there was a reluctance of partners to challenge the CEO even at a senior leadership levels". Read more from Peter Ryan .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in PwC 'integrity failures'

featuredLink.title: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

children.content: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years.

Without naming former chief executives Tom Seymour and Luke Sayers, who are no longer with the firm, the review found a "generally accepted view that the CEO 'runs the show' and there was a reluctance of partners to challenge the CEO even at a senior leadership levels".
Read more from
Peter Ryan

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's largest public sector consulting firm has paused political donations. Andrew Yates, CEO of KPMG Australia, told a Senate inquiry that the company is currently reviewing its policies. He said the company did not give cash donations but mainly hosted events in the past. KPMG along with PwC, Deloitte and EY have donated $4.3 million to major political parties over the past decade. In July, PwC announced it would ban political donations in Australia in an attempt to rebuild trust.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: KPMG pauses political donations

children.content: Australia's largest public sector consulting firm has paused political donations.
Andrew Yates, CEO of KPMG Australia, told a Senate inquiry that the company is currently reviewing its policies.
He said the company did not give cash donations but mainly hosted events in the past.
KPMG along with PwC, Deloitte and EY have donated $4.3 million to major political parties over the past decade.
In July, PwC announced it would
ban political donations in Australia in an attempt to rebuild trust.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: KPMG Australia has been accused of practicing power mapping which the company denies at a Senate inquiry. A document presented by Greens senator Barbara Pocock showed a map of the senior leadership of a firm from whom KPMG had taken enormous money, contradicting KPMG's claim that they do not engage in the practice of power mapping. KPMG is the largest public sector consultant in the country. The firm's boss Andrew Yates denied such practice today at the inquiry. But Senator Pocock said it's breaching trust by not being transparent about their contracts. "We are talking about trust here. This is a breach of trust," she said. "You have breached the Senate's trust and you have breached the trust of the Australian public."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'A breach of trust': KPMG accused of practicing power mapping

children.content: KPMG Australia has been accused of practicing power mapping which the company denies at a Senate inquiry.

A document presented by Greens senator Barbara Pocock showed a map of the senior leadership of a firm from whom KPMG had taken enormous money, contradicting KPMG's claim that they do not engage in the practice of power mapping.
KPMG is the largest public sector consultant in the country.
The firm's boss Andrew Yates denied such practice today at the inquiry.
But Senator Pocock said it's breaching trust by not being transparent about their contracts.
"We are talking about trust here. This is a breach of trust," she said.
"You have breached the Senate's trust and you have breached the trust of the Australian public."

image.altText: Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Trogneux.

props.synopsis: Emmanuel Macron defied expectations in 2017 when he won the French presidency. Many say his self-belief was essential to his victory but it could also risk his global legacy.

title.children: Arrogance, charisma and 'the right path': The gift and the price of Emmanuel Macron's personality

image.altText: A drone image of a railway line under construction, with paddocks either side.

props.synopsis: Work on the multi-billion-dollar Inland Rail project slows significantly in Queensland, as an advocate warns the finished track may only stretch as far north as the state's border with New South Wales.

title.children: 'Father' of Inland Rail project from Melbourne to Brisbane warns line may never reach Toowoomba

image.altText: x-ray of duck laid out wings spread arrow imbedded in rear right side deep all the way into near it's left thigh bone

props.synopsis: Animal advocates say they are seeing more cruelty cases involving wildlife, as a researcher warns of an association between animal abuse and other violent crimes.

title.children: Ducks shot with arrows, brush turkeys spray-painted as vets warn cruelty to wild animals rising

image.altText: A bird's eye view of a concrete crossing over a small creek on green farmland lined with trees.

props.synopsis: Despite having little to do with the Voice, the blowing up of ancient rock shelters and a bungled attempt to preserve Aboriginal heritage are the issues shaping the referendum debate in WA.

title.children: How this banal concrete driveway became emblematic of WA's unique debate on the Voice

image.altText: an aerial shot of three beachfront highrise towers on the Gold Coast

props.synopsis: The Jewel's eye-catching towers are the sparkling gem in the Surfers Paradise skyline, but three years after they were built, hundreds of luxury apartments remain empty and most are not up for sale.

title.children: The curious case of the Jewel and the Gold Coast's near-empty $1.5b towers

image.altText: man stands on stage addressing crowd

props.synopsis: The 17-year-old is in an induced coma after being taken to hospital with a head injury on Tuesday.

title.children: Teenager in induced coma after fall, prompting calls for workplace safety overhaul

image.altText: A man walks on the street holding a plastic bag, which contains a bag of ice.

props.synopsis: Supermarket chain Drakes, which operates more than 60 stores in South Australia and Queensland, is introducing Afterpay as a means of payment — but the move has prompted a warning from a social welfare group, which says it could contribute to spiralling debt.

title.children: Supermarket chain's Afterpay deal triggers 'debt trap' concern from welfare group

image.altText: a composite picture of a rural landscape overlaid with a map of the NSW coast, with a inset picture of a 10-storey high house

props.synopsis: With home gym, rooftop spa, indoor swimming pool and whole-floor tennis court, this 10-storey, single family residence would look at home among the apartment towers of the Gold Coast.

title.children: Is this Australia's tallest house? This 10-storey rural monolith comes with a suspended observation deck

image.altText: Matt Raos during the inquiry sitting in front of a little microphone.

props.synopsis: Qatar Airways says the strip search was currently before the Federal Court so could not comment extensively but provided "assurance" that the incident was a "one off".

title.children: Qatar Airways says invasive strip search of female passengers was a 'one off'

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jumper looks at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A speech pathologist says Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne was running controversial practices as late as February last year.

title.children: Anica has seen a lot in her job, but this experience left her 'physically shaking'

image.altText: Picketers hold signs saying writers guild of america on strike in front of paramount pictures gate

props.synopsis: Leaders of the screenwriters' union say their nearly five-month strike will finish, bringing Hollywood partly back from a historic halt in production.

title.children: Hollywood writers strike to end after guild leaders approve deal with studios

image.altText: Anthony Rota delivers a speech from the speaker's chair in Canada's parliament.

props.synopsis: The speaker of Canada's House of Commons resigns after inviting a man who fought for a Nazi military unit during World War II to parliament to attend a speech by Ukraine's president.

title.children: Canada's speaker quits after man who fought for Nazis received standing ovation in parliament

image.altText: An Australian Kelpie and a woman wearing a red top.

props.synopsis: Violet the dog was vomiting, urinating, and struggling to breathe while suffering a violent high from eating marijuana that had been left at a Brisbane park.

title.children: Violet the kelpie nearly died from a violent high after eating marijuana at a dog park
